title: European sea sturgeon

content.title: External appearance
content.content: In Latvia, the fish is thought to reach up to 20 years of age and to grow up to 2 m long with a weight of 245 kg.

content.title: Distribution
content.content: Historically found throughout Europe, along the coast of the Atlantic Ocean basin, and in the Mediterranean, Black and Baltic Seas. Today, the only naturally breeding population is found in the Garonne river basin in France.

content.title: Diet
content.content: In the sea, it feeds along the seabed on various molluscs, worms, crustaceans and small fish.

content.title: Development
content.content: Spawning migration takes place from the sea to rivers. Sturgeon spawn every second year in summer, when water temperatures are above 20Â° C. Spawning takes place in the swift currents of large and deep rivers, on rocky or gravelly riverbeds.

content.title: Fishing
content.content: Due to the poor state of the population, the species is currently of no importance to either commercial fishing or angling.

fact: Today sturgeon populations in Europe are critically threatened by overfishing, river damming, pollution and climate change. As part of the reintroduction programme, fishermen in Latvian marine waters catch small tagged sturgeon.
